summary: lycorine, a natural alkaloid extracted from Amaryllidaceae, exhibited anti-leukemia effects in vitro and in vivo. survival rate of HL-60 cells exposed to lycorine was decreased, cell growth was slowed down, and cell regeneration potential was inhibited. apoptotic events are regulated by interplay of proapoptotic and antiapoptotic proteins. apoptotic events are regulated by interplay of proapoptotic and antiapoptotic proteins. the death receptor pathway and mitochondria-apoptosome-mediated pathway may represent potential targets for rational tumor therapy. p21-dependent cell cycle arrest occurs at the G2/M phase. the key regulator of the cell division cycle 2 is the cell division cycle 2 (Cdc2)/Cyclin B, the activity of which can be regulated by p21. alkaloids exhibit effective anti-cancer activities with multiple mechanisms. lycorine induced apoptosis in human leukemia cells via the mitochondria pathway and increased the Bax:Bcl-2 ratio through the down-regulation of Bcl-2 expression. lycorine exerted its in vitro antitumor activity through cytostatic rather than cytotoxic effects. lycorine significantly up-regulate p21 mRNA and protein in a concentration-dependent manner after treatment with lycorine. results showed that these proteins were significantly down-regulated in a concentration-dependent manner after treatment with p21. expression level of truncated Bid (tBid) decreased when lycorine concentration reached 5.0 M. expression level of truncated Bid (tBid) was significantly increased in a concentration-dependent manner. cytochrome c appeared red when stained with cyanine 3 (Cy3) fluorochrome. staining patterns of cytochrome c became diffuse and blurred. some red dye entered the nucleus and mixed with the blue stain to yield a purple-stained nucleus. the expression of NF-B protein in the nucleus decreased significantly in HL-60 cells treated with different concentrations of lycorine. immunocytochemistry results showed that lycorine significantly blocked the nuclear import of NF-B protein. lycorine was distributed in the cytoplasm (D4, D6) in HL-60 cells treated with lycorine. HL-60 cells treated with 0, 1.25, 2.5, and 5.0 M lycorine. p21 is tightly controlled by the tumour suppressor protein p53. p53 mediates the p53-dependent cell-cycle arrest at G1 phase. lycorine regulated the expression of p21 and then influenced the expression of down-stream genes Cyclin B-Cdc2 and Cyclin E-Cdk2. p21 also functions as a proapoptotic molecule in the HL-60 cell line, a p53-indeficient leukemia cell line. this implies that the up-regulation of p21 go through p53-independent pathways, and it is possible that p21 acts as p21 mediated crosstalk between lycorine-induced apoptosis in HL-60 cells. p21 may also play an important role in apoptosis induced by activation of members of the TNF death receptor family. NF-B regulates the transcription of many genes related to immune and inflammatory responses.
